name: to_unix_epoch_seconds
description: Return the number of seconds from the Unix epoch start (1.1.1970)  If this Date_Time is before the epoch start, returns a negative number.

name: to_unix_epoch_milliseconds
description: Return the number of milliseconds from the Unix epoch start.  If this Date_Time is before an epoch start, returns a negative number.

name: to_enso_epoch_seconds
description: Return the number of seconds from the Enso epoch start.  See `Date_Time.enso_epoch_start`.

name: to_enso_epoch_milliseconds
description: Return the number of milliseconds from the Enso epoch start.  See `Date_Time.enso_epoch_start`.

name: time_of_day
description: Convert this point in time to time of day, discarding the time zone information.

name: week_of_year
description: Returns the number of week of year this date falls into.  Produces a warning for a Date that is before epoch start.
remarks: ! Locale Dependency   Note that this operation is locale-specific. It varies both by the   local definition of the first day of week and the definition of the   first week of year. For example, in the US, the first day of the week   is Sunday and week 1 is the week containing January 1. In the UK on the   other hand, the first day of the week is Monday, and week 1 is the week   containing the first Thursday of the year. Therefore it is important to   properly specify the `locale` argument.

name: is_leap_year
description: Returns if the date is in a leap year.  Produces a warning for a Date that is before epoch start.

name: length_of_year
description: Returns the number of days in the year represented by this date.  Produces a warning for a Date that is before epoch start.

name: century
description: Returns the century of the date.

name: quarter
description: Returns the quarter of the year the date falls into.

name: length_of_month
description: Returns the number of days in the month represented by this date.  Produces a warning for a Date that is before epoch start.

name: day_of_year
description: Returns the day of the year.

name: day_of_week
description: Returns the day of the week.

name: start_of
description: Returns the first date within the `Time_Period` or `Date_Period` containing self.

name: end_of
description: Returns the last date within the `Time_Period` or `Date_Period` containing self.

name: date
description: Convert this point in time to date, discarding the time of day information.

name: at_zone
description: Convert the time instant to the same instant in the provided time zone.

name: date_part
description: Returns a requested date-time part as integer.  Produces a warning for a Date_Time that is before epoch start. See `Date_Time.enso_epoch_start`.

name: date_diff
description: Computes a time difference between the two date-times.  It returns an integer expressing how many periods fit between the two date-times.  The difference will be positive if `end` is greater than `self`.  Produces a warning for a Date_Time that is before epoch start. See `Date_Time.enso_epoch_start`.

name: date_add
description: Shifts the date-time by a specified period.  Produces a warning for a Date_Time that is before epoch start. See `Date_Time.enso_epoch_start`.
Add the specified amount of time to this instant to produce a new instant.

name: add_work_days
description: Shift the date by the specified amount of business days.  For the purpose of this method, the business days are defined to be Monday through Friday.  Produces a warning if called on a Date_Time that is before an epoch start. See `Date_Time.enso_epoch_start`.  This method always returns a day which is a business day - if the shift amount is zero, the closest following business day is returned. For the purpose of calculating the shift, the holidays are treated as if we were starting at the next business day after them, for example counting the shift starting on Saturday or Sunday works as if we were counting the shift from Monday (for positive shifts). So shifting Sunday by zero days will return Monday, but shifting it by one day will return a Tuesday (so that there is the full work day - Monday) within the interval. For negative shifts, shifting either Saturday or Sunday one day backwards will return Friday, but shifting Monday one day backwards will return a Friday. The whole logic is made consistent with `work_days_until`, so that the following properties hold:     date.work_days_until (date.add_work_days N) == N for any N >= 0     (date.add_work_days N).work_days_until date == -N for any N < 0  The time of day is preserved, only the date is shifted.
Subtract the specified amount of time from this instant to get a new instant.  Produces a warning if the resulting date time is before an Enso epoch.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert to a display representation of this Date_Time.

name: pretty
description: Convert the value to a corresponding Enso code representation.

name: to_js_object
description: Convert to a JavaScript Object representing a Date_Time.

name: format
description: Format this time as text using the specified format specifier.
remarks: ? Pattern Syntax   If the pattern is provided as `Text`, it is parsed using the format   described below. See `Date_Time_Formatter` for more options.   - y: Year. The number of pattern letters determines the minimum number of     digits.     - y: The year using any number of digits.     - yy: The year, using at most two digits. The default range is       1950-2049, but this can be changed by including the end year in       braces e.g. `yy{2099}`.     - yyyy: The year, using exactly four digits.   - M: Month of year. The number of pattern letters determines the format:     - M: Any number (1-12).     - MM: Month number with zero padding required (01-12).     - MMM: Short name of the month (Jan-Dec).     - MMMM: Full name of the month (January-December).     The month names depend on the selected locale.   - d: Day. The number of pattern letters determines the format:     - d: Any number (1-31).     - dd: Day number with zero padding required (01-31).     - ddd: Short name of the day of week (Mon-Sun).     - dddd: Full name of the day of week (Monday-Sunday).     The weekday names depend on the selected locale.     Both day of week and day of month may be included in a single pattern -     in such case the day of week is used as a sanity check.   - Q: Quarter of year.     If only year and quarter are provided in the pattern, when parsing a     date, the result will be the first day of that quarter.   - H: 24h hour of day (0-23).   - h: 12h hour of day (0-12). The `a` pattern is needed to disambiguate     between AM and PM.   - m: Minute of hour.   - s: Second of minute.   - f: Fractional part of the second. The number of pattern letters     determines the number of digits. If one letter is used, any number of     digits will be accepted.   - a: AM/PM marker.   - T: If repeated 3 or less times - Time zone ID (e.g. Europe/Warsaw, Z,     -08:30), otherwise - Time zone name (e.g. Central European Time, CET).   - Z: Zone offset.     - Z, ZZ, ZZZ: A short offset form (+HHmm).       No offset is indicated by "+0000". This can be customized by setting       an alternative no offset string in curly braces, e.g. `zz{Z}`.     - ZZZZ: Localized offset (e.g. GMT-08:00).     - ZZZZZ: A full offset form (+HH:mm:ss).       No offset is indicated by "Z". This can be customized as above, e.g.       `ZZZZZ{0}`.

name: new_builtin
description:
Obtains an instance of `Date_Time` from a year, month, day, hour, minute, second, nanosecond and timezone. 

 Recommended to use `Date_Time.new` instead which handles potential exceptions.

name: from_simple_pattern
description: Creates a formatter from a simple date-time format pattern.  Every letter in the pattern is interpreted as a pattern character as described in the table below. Any character that is not a letter in the pattern is treated as a literal character. If a sequence of letters needs to be put in as a literal, it can be escaped using single quotes. Use two single quotes in a row to represent a single quote in the result. As explained below, curly braces can have special meaning (see 'yy'); to enter a literal curly brace, put it inside a quoted literal.  Pattern characters are interpreted case insensitively, with the exception of `M/m' and 'H/h'.
remarks:
? Date pattern characters  - y: Year. The number of pattern letters determines the minimum number of   digits.   - y: The year using any number of digits.   - yy: The year, using at most two digits. The default range is     1950-2049, but this can be changed by including the end year in     braces e.g. `yy{2099}`.   - yyyy: The year, using exactly four digits. - M: Month of year. The number of pattern letters determines the format:   - M: Any number (1-12).   - MM: Month number with zero padding required (01-12).   - MMM: Short name of the month (Jan-Dec).   - MMMM: Full name of the month (January-December).   The month names depend on the selected locale. - d: Day. The number of pattern letters determines the format:   - d: Any number (1-31).   - dd: Day number with zero padding required (01-31).   - ddd: Short name of the day of week (Mon-Sun).   - dddd: Full name of the day of week (Monday-Sunday).   The weekday names depend on the selected locale.   Both day of week and day of month may be included in a single pattern -   in such case the day of week is used as a sanity check. - e: An alternative notation: single `e` maps to `ddd` and `ee` or more   map to `dddd` meaning name of day of week. - Q: Quarter of year.   If only year and quarter are provided in the pattern, when parsing a   date, the result will be the first day of that quarter. 

? Time pattern characters  - H: 24h hour of day (0-23). - h: 12h hour of day (0-12). The `a` pattern is needed to disambiguate   between AM and PM. - m: Minute of hour. - s: Second of minute. - f: Fractional part of the second. The number of pattern letters   determines the number of digits. If one letter is used, any number of   digits will be accepted. - a: AM/PM marker. 

? Time zone pattern characters  - T: If repeated 3 or less times - Time zone ID (e.g. Europe/Warsaw, Z,   -08:30), otherwise - Time zone name (e.g. Central European Time, CET). - Z: Zone offset.   - Z, ZZ, ZZZ: A short offset form (+HHmm).     No offset is indicated by "+0000". This can be customized by setting     an alternative no offset string in curly braces, e.g. `zz{Z}`.   - ZZZZ: Localized offset (e.g. GMT-08:00).   - ZZZZZ: A full offset form (+HH:mm:ss).     No offset is indicated by "Z". This can be customized as above, e.g.     `ZZZZZ{0}`. - v: Time zone name (same as TTTT). - V: Time zone ID (same as T).  Some parts, like fractions of a second may not be required. The square brackets `[]` can be used to surround such optional sections.

name: from_iso_week_date_pattern
description: Creates a formatter from a pattern for the ISO 8601 leap week calendar.  The ISO 8601 leap week calendar is a variation of the ISO 8601 calendar that defines a leap week as the week that contains the 29th of February. This calendar is used by some European and Middle Eastern countries.  The pattern is a sequence of letters and symbols that are interpreted as follows: - Y: The week based year.   - In case the year is parsed in two digit mode (`YY`), the default     range is 1950-2049, but this can be changed by including the end year     in braces e.g. `YY{2099}` - w: Week of year. - d: Day of week.   - d: Numeric day of week (1-7). 1 is Monday.   - dd: Numeric day of week with zero padding (01-07).   - ddd: Short name of the day of week (Mon-Sun).   - dddd: Full name of the day of week (Monday-Sunday).   The weekday names depend on the selected locale. - e: An alternative notation: single `e` maps to `ddd` and `ee` or more   map to `dddd` meaning name of day of week.  Moreover, all time and timezone pattern characters like in `Simple` case are supported too - in case you need to parse a date time value with the date part in ISO week date format.  The same as in the `Simple` pattern, the single quotes can be used to escape letter literals and square brackets can be used to indicate optional sections.

name: from_java
description: Creates a formatter from a Java `DateTimeFormatter` instance or a text pattern parsed using the Java parser: `DateTimeFormatter.ofPattern`.  See the Java documentation for explanation of the pattern format: https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/time/format/DateTimeFormatter.html#patterns

name: default_enso_zoned_date_time
description: The default format for date-time used in Enso. It acts as `ISO_Zoned_Date_Time` but both offset and timezone are optional.  For example, it may parse date of the form `2011-12-03 10:15:30+01:00[Europe/Paris]`, as well as `2011-12-03T10:15:30` assuming the default timezone.

name: iso_zoned_date_time
description: The ISO 8601 format for date-time with offset and timezone. The date and time parts may be separated by a single space or a `T`.  For example, it may parse date of the form `2011-12-03 10:15:30+01:00[Europe/Paris]`.

name: iso_offset_date_time
description: The ISO 8601 format for date-time with offset. The date and time parts may be separated by a single space or a `T`.  For example, it may parse date of the form `2011-12-03 10:15:30+01:00`.

name: iso_local_date_time
description: The ISO 8601 format for date-time without a timezone. The date and time parts may be separated by a single space or a `T`.  For example, it may parse date of the form `2011-12-03 10:15:30`. The timezone will be set to `Time_Zone.system`.

name: iso_date
description: The ISO 8601 format for date.  For example, it may parse date of the form `2011-12-03`.

name: iso_time
description: The ISO 8601 format for time.  For example, it may parse time of the form `10:15:30`.

name: to_text
description: Returns a text representation of this formatter.

name: to_display_text
description: Parses a human-readable representation of this formatter.

name: with_locale
description: Returns a copy of this formatter with a changed locale.

name: with_parsing_warnings
description: Adds parsing warnings, if any, to the result of `continuation`.

name: get_java_formatter_for_parsing
description: Returns the `underlying` formatter, also ensuring that parse-only warnings are attached to it, to be propagated.

name: pattern_approximation_as_text
description: Returns a pattern that is associated with this formatter.  For formatters created using `from_simple_pattern` and `from_iso_week_date_pattern` or `from_java` with a Text pattern this will just be the pattern. For constants, it will be a pattern that best resembles that constant. For formatters created from a Java formatter instance, this will be the text representation of that formatter.

This type is a date-time object that represents a time, often viewed as hour-minute-second.  Time is represented to nanosecond precision. For example, the value "13:45.30.123456789" can be stored in a `Time_Of_Day`.

name: now
description: Obtains the current time from the system clock in the default time-zone.

name: new
description:
Obtains an instance of `Time_Of_Day` from an hour, minute, second and nanosecond. 

 Returns a `Time_Error` if the provided time is not a valid time.

name: parse
description:
Obtains an instance of `Time_Of_Day` from a text such as "10:15". 

 Returns a `Time_Error` if the provided text cannot be parsed using the default format.
remarks:
? Default Time Format   Unless you provide a custom format, the text must represent a valid   time and is parsed using the ISO-8601 extended local time format.   The format consists of:    - Two digits for the hour-of-day. This is pre-padded by zero to ensure two     digits.   - A colon   - Two digits for the minute-of-hour. This is pre-padded by zero to ensure     two digits.   - If the second-of-minute is not available then the format is complete.   - A colon   - Two digits for the second-of-minute. This is pre-padded by zero to ensure     two digits.   - If the nano-of-second is zero or not available then the format is     complete.   - A decimal point   - One to nine digits for the nano-of-second. As many digits will be output     as required. 

? Pattern Syntax   If the pattern is provided as `Text`, it is parsed using the format   described below. See `Date_Time_Formatter` for more options.   - H: 24h hour of day (0-23).   - h: 12h hour of day (0-12). The `a` pattern is needed to disambiguate     between AM and PM.   - m: Minute of hour.   - s: Second of minute.   - f: Fractional part of the second. The number of pattern letters     determines the number of digits. If one letter is used, any number of     digits will be accepted.   - a: AM/PM marker.

name: sort
description:
Sort the array. 

 By default, elements are sorted in ascending order.  This is a stable sort, meaning that items that compare the same will not have their order changed by the sorting process.
remarks:
! Computational Complexity   The complexities for this sort are:   - *Worst-Case Time:* `O(n * log n)`   - *Best-Case Time:* `O(n)`   - *Average Time:* `O(n * log n)`   - *Worst-Case Space:* `O(n)` additional 

? Incomparable values   Incomparable values are either values with different comparators or with   the same comparator returning `Nothing` from its `compare` method.   See the documentation of the `Ordering` module for more info. 

? Implementation Note   The sort implementation is based upon an adaptive, iterative mergesort   that requires far fewer than `n * log(n)` comparisons when the array   is partially sorted. When the array is randomly ordered, the   performance is equivalent to a standard mergesort. 

? Multiple comparators   Elements with different comparators are incomparable by definition.   This case is handled by first grouping the `self` array into groups   with the same comparator, recursively sorting these groups, and then   merging them back together. The order of the sorted groups in the   resulting array is based on the order of fully qualified names of   the comparators in the `self` array, with the exception of the group   for the default comparator, which is always the first group.    Additionally, an `Incomparable_Values` dataflow error will be returned   if the `on_problems` parameter is set to `Report_Error`, or a warning   attached if the `on_problems` parameter is set to `Report_Warning` in   case of encountering incomparable values.    It takes equal advantage of ascending and descending runs in the array,   making it much simpler to merge two or more sorted arrays: simply   concatenate them and sort.

name: take
description: Creates a new `Vector` with only the specified range of elements from the input, removing any elements outside the range.

name: drop
description: Creates a new `Vector`, removing any elements from the specified range.

name: insert
description: Inserts the given item into the array at the given index.

name: remove
description: Removes the item at the given index from the array.

name: first
description: Get the first element from the array, or an `Index_Out_Of_Bounds` if the array is empty.

name: second
description: Get the second element from the array, or a `Index_Out_Of_Bounds` if the array doesn't have a second element.  Useful when tuples are implemented as arrays.

name: last
description: Get the last element of the array, or an `Index_Out_Of_Bounds` if the array is empty.

name: index_of
description: Returns the index of an element in the array. Returns Nothing if the element is not found.

name: last_index_of
description: Returns the last index of an element in the array. Returns `Nothing` if the element is not found.

name: is_empty
description: Checks if this array is empty.

name: to_list
description: Converts the array to a list with the same elements.

name: distinct
description:
Keeps only unique elements within the array, removing any duplicates. 

 The returned unique elements are kept in the same order as they appeared in the input.  Out of multiple equivalent (equal up to the `on` projection) elements, always the one appearing first in the input is kept.

name: duplicates
description:
Returns only non-unique elements within the array. 

 The returned duplicate elements are kept in the same order as the first duplicate appeared in the input.

name: map
description: Applies a function to each element of the array, returning the `Vector` of results.

name: flat_map
description: Applies a function to each element of the array, returning the `Vector` that contains all results concatenated.

name: filter
description: Selects all elements of this array which satisfy a condition.

name: flatten
description: Transforms an array of arrays into a `Vector` of inner elements - removes one layer of nesting from a stack of nested arrays.

name: running_fold
description: Combines all the elements of the array, by iteratively applying the passed function with the next element of the array. After each step the value is stored resulting in a new array of the same size as self.

name: fold
description:
Combines all the elements of the array, by iteratively applying the passed function with next elements of the array. 

 In general, the result of     [l0, l1, ..., ln].to_array . fold init f is the same as     f (...(f (f init l0) l1)...) ln

name: fold_with_index
description: Combines all the elements of the array, by iteratively applying the passed function with next elements of the array.

name: pad
description:
Extend `self` array to the length of `n` appending elements `elem` to the end. 

 If the new length `n` is less than existing length, `self` array is returned.

name: partition
description: Partitions the array into `Vector`s of elements which satisfy a given condition and ones that do not.  Returns a `Pair` whose `first` element is the `Vector` of elements satisfying the predicate and the `second` element is a `Vector` of elements which did not satisfy it.  The relative order of elements kept in each returned list is the same as in the input array.

name: partition_with_index
description: Partitions the array into `Vector`s of elements which satisfy a given predicate and ones that do not.  Returns a `Pair` whose `first` element is the `Vector` of elements satisfying the predicate and the `second` element is a `Vector` of elements which did not satisfy it.  The relative order of elements kept in each returned list is the same as in the input array.

name: transpose
description: Swaps the rows and columns of a matrix represented by an array of arrays.

name: map_with_index
description:
Applies a function to each element of the array, returning the `Vector` of results. 

 The function is called with both the element index as well as the element itself.

name: slice
description: Creates a new array with the skipping elements until `start` and then continuing until `end` index.

name: find
description: Returns the first element of the array that satisfies the condition or `if_missing` if no elements of the array satisfy it.

name: get
description: Gets an element from the array at a specified index (0-based). If the index is invalid then `if_missing` is returned.

name: not_empty
description: Checks if this array is not empty.

name: filter_with_index
description: Selects all elements of this array which satisfy a predicate.

name: join

separator.comment: - separator (optional): The text to use to join the textual elements of the array.

prefix.comment: - prefix (optional): The prefix to add at the beginning.

suffix.comment: - suffix (optional): The suffix to add at the end.

description: When `self` is an array of text values, concatenates all the values by interspersing them with `separator`.

name: to_text
description: Generates a human-readable text representation of the array.

name: pretty
description: Convert the value to a corresponding Enso code representation.

name: reduce
description: Combines all the elements of a non-empty array using a binary operation. If the array is empty, it returns `if_empty`.

name: any
description: Checks whether a predicate holds for at least one element of self array.

name: all
description: Checks whether a condition holds for all elements in this array.

name: contains
description: Checks whether this array contains a given value as an element.

name: zip
description:
Performs a pair-wise operation passed in `function` on consecutive elements of `self` and `that`. 

 The result of this function is a `Vector` of length being the shorter of `self` and `that`, containing results of calling `function`.

name: to_vector
description: Returns the array as a `Vector`.

name: reverse
description: Reverses the array, returning a `Vector` with the same elements, but in the opposite order.

name: each
description: Applies a function to each element of the array.  Unlike `map`, this method does not return the individual results, therefore it is only useful for side-effecting computations.  If the function returns a dataflow error, the error is converted to a panic and thrown immediately stopping further processing.

name: each_with_index
description:
Applies a function to each element of the array. 

 The function is called with both the element index as well as the element itself.  Unlike `map`, this method does not return the individual results, therefore it is only useful for side-effecting computations.

name: False

name: if_then_else
description:
The if-then-else control flow operator that executes one of two branches based on a conditional. 

 Both of the arguments to this method are _lazy_, meaning that they will only be evaluated if they are needed (based on the condition).

name: if_then
description:
The if-then control flow operator that executes a branch if the condition is true, and otherwise returns Nothing. 

 The argument to this method is _lazy_, meaning that it will only be evaluated if the this evaluates to True.

name: new
description: Construct a `Decimal` from a `Text`, `Integer` or `Float`.
remarks:
? Number Format    The textual format for a Decimal is defined at   https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/math/BigDecimal.html#BigDecimal-java.lang.String-. 

? Creating `Decimal`s and Converting to `Decimal`    When creating a `Decimal` from a literal floating-point value, the   preferred method is to express the literal as a string and use   `Decimal.from_text`, since this will give a `Decimal` that matches the   value precisely.    To convert a `Float` or `Integer` to a `Decimal`, use its `.to_decimal`   method.    You can also use the convenience method `dec` to convert any `Integer`,   `Float`, or `Text` value to a `Decimal`. `dec` does not attach a   warning.

name: from_text
description: Construct a `Decimal` from a `Text`.
remarks:
? Number Format    The textual format for a Decimal is defined at   https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/math/BigDecimal.html#BigDecimal-java.lang.String-. 

? Creating `Decimal`s and Converting to `Decimal`    When creating a `Decimal` from a literal floating-point value, the   preferred method is to express the literal as a string and use   `Decimal.from_text`, since this will give a `Decimal` that matches the   value precisely.    To convert a `Float` or `Integer` to a `Decimal`, use its `.to_decimal`   method.    You can also use the convenience method `dec` to convert any `Integer`,   `Float`, or `Text` value to a `Decimal`. `dec` does not attach a   warning.

name: from_integer
description: Construct a `Decimal` from an `Integer`.
remarks: ? Creating `Decimal`s and Converting to `Decimal`    When creating a `Decimal` from a literal floating-point value, the   preferred method is to express the literal as a string and use   `Decimal.from_text`, since this will give a `Decimal` that matches the   value precisely.    To convert a `Float` or `Integer` to a `Decimal`, use its `.to_decimal`   method.    You can also use the convenience method `dec` to convert any `Integer`,   `Float`, or `Text` value to a `Decimal`. `dec` does not attach a   warning.

name: from_float
description: Construct a `Decimal` from a `Float`.
remarks:
? Precision Loss    A `Decimal` can represent any `Float` precisely. However, some `Float`   literals, such as `0.1`, cannot be represented exactly to infinite   precision by a `Float`. For this reason, constructing a `Decimal` from   a `Float` always attaches a `Loss_Of_Numeric_Precision` warning to the   result. 

? Creating `Decimal`s and Converting to `Decimal`    When creating a `Decimal` from a literal floating-point value, the   preferred method is to express the literal as a string and use   `Decimal.from_text`, since this will give a `Decimal` that matches the   value precisely.    To convert a `Float` or `Integer` to a `Decimal`, use its `.to_decimal`   method.    You can also use the convenience method `dec` to convert any `Integer`,   `Float`, or `Text` value to a `Decimal`. `dec` does not attach a   warning.

name: parse
description: Parses a string into a `Decimal`, returning a `Number_Parse_Error` if the text does not represent a valid `Decimal`.

description:
Adds a `Decimal` to another `Decimal` or other kind of number. A `Math_Context` value can be specified to set the precision and `Rounding_Mode`. 

 Arguments to `add` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

Adds a `Decimal` to another `Decimal` or other kind of number. 

 Arguments to `+` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

name: subtract
description:
Subtract a `Decimal` or other kind of number from another `Decimal`, or subtract  a `Decimal` from another kind of number. A `Math_Context` value can be specified to set the precision and `Rounding_Mode`. 

 Arguments to `subtract` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

Subtract a `Decimal` or other kind of number from another `Decimal`, or subtract  a `Decimal` from another kind of number. 

 Arguments to `-` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

name: multiply
description:
Multiplies a `Decimal` by another `Decimal` or other kind of number. A `Math_Context` value can be specified to set the precision and `Rounding_Mode`. 

 Arguments to `multiply` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

Multiplies a `Decimal` by another `Decimal` or other kind of number. 

 Arguments to `*` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

name: divide
description:
Divide a `Decimal` by another `Decimal` or other kind of number, or divide another kind of number by a `Decimal`. A `Math_Context` value can be specified to set the precision and `Rounding_Mode`. 

 Arguments to `divide` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

Divides a `Decimal` by another `Decimal` or other kind of number, or divides another kind of number by a `Decimal`. 

 Arguments to `/` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

name: remainder
description:
Computes the remainder when dividing this by that. 

 Arguments to `remainder` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.
remarks: ? Negative Arguments    When the first argument to `remainder` is negative, the result will   also be negative.

description:
Computes the remainder when dividing this by that. 

 Arguments to `%` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.
remarks: ? Negative Arguments    When the first argument to `%` is negative, the result will also be   negative.

name: div
description:
Computes the integer division of this by that. 

 Integer division of Decimals rounds down to the nearest integer.  Arguments to `div` will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert other numeric types to `Decimal` manually.

name: pow
description: Compute the result of raising this to the positive integer power `exp`.
Compute the result of raising this to the positive integer power `exp`.

name: negate
description: Compute the negation of this.

name: abs
description: Computes the absolute value of this.  The absolute value of a positive number is itself, while the absolute value of a negative number is that number multiplied by -1.

name: signum
description: Returns the sign of the number.

name: min
description: Returns the smaller value of `self` and `that`.

name: max
description: Returns the larger value of `self` and `that`.

name: to_integer
description: Convert this to an `Integer`.  Conversion to `Integer` uses truncation: the fractional portion is dropped.  If the conversion resulted in a loss of precision, a `Loss_Of_Numeric_Precision` warning is attached.

name: to_float
description: Convert this to a `Float`.
remarks:
? Precision Loss    While any `Float` can be precisely represented by a `Decimal`, not   every `Decimal` can be accurange represented by a `Float`, so this   conversion can lose precision. For this reason, converting a   `Decimal` to a `Float` always attaches a `Loss_Of_Numeric_Precision`   warning to the result. 

? Representable Values    If the `Decimal` is outside the representable range of `Float` (which   is `(-Double.MAX_VALUE, Double.MAX_VALUE)`, inclusive), `+/-Inf` is   returned, and an `Out_Of_Range` warning is attached.

name: round
description: Round to a specified number of decimal places.  By default, rounding uses "symmetric round-half-up", also known as "half-up." If use_bankers=True, then it uses "round-half-even", also known as "banker's rounding".
remarks: ? Negative decimal place counts   Rounding to `n` digits can be thought of as "rounding to the nearest   multiple of 10^(-n)". For negative decimal counts, this results in   rounding to the nearest positive integer power of 10.

name: ceil
description: Computes the nearest `Integer` equal to or above this number.

name: floor
description: Computes the nearest `Integer` equal to or below this number.

name: truncate
description: Truncate a number to an `Integer` to by dropping the fractional part. This is equivalent to "round-toward-zero".

name: format
description: Converts a `Decimal` to a string, using the Java `DecimalFormat` formatter.  For details about the `DecimalFormat` format specifier, see https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/text/DecimalFormat.html.

name: set_scale
description: Change the scale of a Decimal.  A `Decimal` value is represented internally by a Java `BigInteger` "unscaled value" and a "scale value". The numerical value of the `Decimal` is `(unscaledValue * 10^(-scale))`. Scale values are maintained automatically by the constructors and numerical operations, but can also be set explicitly.  Scale values can allow distinctions between values that would be identical as `Float`s. For example, the following values have different internal representations:      a = Decimal.new "2.0"     b = Decimal.new "2.00"     a == b     # => True  These two values have different internal representations, but they are still considered the same value by `==`.

name: to_text
description: Note: the underlying Java `BigDecimal` implementation is not affected by locale.

name: to_display_text

name: to_text_without_scientific_notation

name: dec
description: Construct a `Decimal` from a `Text`, `Integer` or `Float`.
remarks: ? Number Format      The textual format for a Decimal is defined at     https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/math/BigDecimal.html#BigDecimal-java.lang.String-.

name: get_big_decimal
description: Helper method allowing access to the backing field.

name: from_big_decimal
description: Create a Decimal from the Java backing field.

A key-value store. It is possible to use any type as keys and values and mix them in one Dictionary. Keys are checked for equality based on their hash code and `==` operator, which is both an internal part of Enso. Enso is capable of computing a hash code, and checking for equality any objects that can appear in Enso - primitives, Atoms, values coming from different languages, etc.  For keys that are not reflexive, like `Number.nan`, [Same Value equality specification](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Equality_comparisons_and_sameness#same-value-zero_equality) is used. This means that both `Number.nan` and types with comparators that violate reflexivity (e.g. their `compare` method always returns `Nothing`) can be used as keys in the Dictionary.  A single key-value pair is called an *entry*.  It is possible to pass a Dictionary created in Enso to foreign functions, where it will be treated as appropriate map structures - in Python that is a dictionary, and in JavaScript, it is a `Map`. And likewise, it is possible to pass a foreign map into Enso, where it will be treated as a Dictionary.

name: empty
description: Returns an empty dictionary.

name: singleton
description: Returns a single-element dictionary with the given key and value. A Call to `Dictionary.singleton key value` is the same as a call to `Dictionary.empty.insert key value`.

name: from_keys_and_values
description: Builds a dictionary from two Vectors. The first vector contains the keys, and the second vector contains the values. The two vectors must be of the same length.

name: from_vector
description: Builds a dictionary from a vector of key-value pairs, with each key-value pair represented as a 2 element vector.

name: is_empty
description: Returns True if the Dictionary is empty, i.e. does not have any entries.

name: not_empty
description: Returns True if the Dictionary is not empty, i.e. has at least one entry.

name: size
description: Returns the number of entries in this dictionary.

name: length
description: Returns the number of entries in this dictionary.

name: insert
description: Inserts a key-value mapping into this dictionary, overriding any existing instance of `key` with the new `value`.  Note that since the return type is also a `Dictionary`, multiple `insert` calls can be chained, e.g., `dictionary.insert "A" 1 . insert "B" 2`.  Due to the limitation of the current implementation, inserts with a key that is already contained in the dictionary, or insert on a dictionary instance that is re-used in other computations, have a linear time complexity. For all the other cases, the time complexity of this method is constant.

name: remove
description: Removes an entry specified by the given key from this dictionary, and returns a new dictionary without this entry. Throw `No_Such_Key.Error` if `key` is not present.

name: at
description: Gets the value associated with `key` in this dictionary, or throws a `No_Such_Key.Error` if `key` is not present.  This method has a constant time complexity.

name: get
description: Gets the value associated with `key` in this dictionary, or returns `if_missing` if it isn't present.  This method has a constant time complexity.

name: contains_key
description: Returns True iff the Dictionary contains the given `key`.

name: keys
description: Returns an unsorted vector of all the keys in this Dictionary.

name: values
description: Returns an unsorted vector of all the values in this Dictionary.

name: map
description: Maps a function over each value in this dictionary.

name: map_with_key
description: Maps a function over each key-value pair in the dictionary, transforming the value.

name: map_keys
description: Maps a function over each key in this dictionary.

name: transform
description: Transforms the map's keys and values to create a new dictionary.

name: fold
description: Combines the values in the dictionary.

name: fold_with_key
description: Combines the key-value pairs in the dictionary.

name: each
description:
Applies a function to each value in the dictionary. 

 This method does not return the results, so it is only useful for performing computations with side-effects.  If the function returns a dataflow error, the error is converted to a panic and thrown immediately stopping further processing.

name: each_with_key
description:
Applies a function to each key-value pair in the dictionary. 

 This method does not return the results, so it is only useful for performing computations with side-effects.

name: to_vector
description: Returns an unsorted vector of key-value pairs (nested 2 element vectors). `Dictionary.from_vector` method is an inverse method, so the following expression is true for all dictionaries: `Dictionary.from_vector dictionary.to_vector == dictionary`.

name: to_text
description: Returns a text representation of this Dictionary.

name: Less
description: Is less than a value (or another column, in case of Table operations)?

name: Equal_Or_Less
description: Is less than or equal to a value (or another column, in case of Table operations)?

name: Equal
description: Is equal to a value (or another column, in case of Table operations)?

name: Equal_Or_Greater
description: Is greater than or equal to a value (or another column, in case of Table operations)?

name: Greater
description: Is greater than a value (or another column, in case of Table operations)?

name: Not_Equal
description: Is not equal to a value (or another column, in case of Table operations)?

name: Between
description: Is between (inclusive) two values (or columns, in case of Table operations)?

name: Equal_Ignore_Case
description: Is equal to another value, ignoring case (Text only)?
remarks:
? Table Operations   It accepts a Text value to check if the value equals to it. In case of   Table operations, it can accept another column - then the corresponding   values from the source column and the provided column are checked. 

! Unicode Equality   The definition of equality includes Unicode canonicalization. I.e. two   texts are equal if they are identical after canonical decomposition.   This ensures that different ways of expressing the same character in   the underlying binary representation are considered equal.

name: Starts_With
description: Does the value start with a prefix (Text only)?
remarks: ? Table Operations   It accepts a Text value to check if the value contains it. In case of   Table operations, it can accept another column - then the corresponding   values from the source column and the provided column are checked.

name: Ends_With
description: Does the value end with a suffix (Text only)?
remarks: ? Table Operations   It accepts a Text value to check if the value contains it. In case of   Table operations, it can accept another column - then the corresponding   values from the source column and the provided column are checked.

name: Contains
description: Does the value contain the substring (Text only)?
remarks: ? Table Operations   It accepts a Text value to check if the value contains it. In case of   Table operations, it can accept another column - then the corresponding   values from the source column and the provided column are checked.

name: Is_Nothing
description: Is equal to Nothing?

name: Not_Nothing
description: Is not equal to Nothing?

name: Is_Nan

name: Not_Nan

name: Is_Infinite

name: Is_Finite

name: Is_True

name: Is_False

name: Is_Empty
description: Is equal to "" or Nothing (Text only)?

name: Not_Empty
description: Is not equal to "" and Nothing (Text only)?

name: Like
description: Does the value match the SQL pattern (Text only)?  The pattern is interpreted according to the standard SQL convention: - the `%` character matches any sequence of characters, - the `_` character matches any single character, - any other character is matched literally.
remarks:
? Table Operations   It accepts a Text value to check if the value contains it. In case of   Table operations, it can accept another column - then the corresponding   values from the source column and the provided column are checked. 

! Known Limitations.   The Truffle regex engine does not transparently handle normalization.   Due to this limitation, Unicode normalization has been disabled for   this function, so beware that some equivalent graphemes like '' and   's\u0301' will not be matched.

name: Regex_Match
description: Does the value match the regular expression pattern (Text only)?
remarks:
? Table Operations   It accepts a Text value to check if the value contains it. In case of   Table operations, it can accept another column - then the corresponding   values from the source column and the provided column are checked. 

! Known Limitations.   The Truffle regex engine does not transparently handle normalization.   Due to this limitation, Unicode normalization has been disabled for   this function, so beware that some equivalent graphemes like '' and   's\u0301' will not be matched.

name: Is_In
description: Is the value contained in `values`?
remarks: ? Table Operations   It accepts a `Vector` of values. In case of Table operations, it can   also accept another column - then it acts as if `column.to_vector` was   passed - i.e. every element of the original table's column is checked   if it is contained in the provided column. The columns can have   different lengths.    Using Columns can be particularly useful for Database operations, as   uploading a temporary table and using its column for an `Is_In` check   will likely be faster than using the vector directly.

description: Checks if the set is not empty.

name: contains
description: Checks if this set contains a given value.

name: contains_relational
description: Checks if this set contains a given value, treating Nothing as a relational NULL.  If the argument is non-Nothing and exists in `value`, return true.  If the argument is non-Nothing and does not exist in `value`, return false if `value` does not contain a Nothing, or Nothing if `value` does contain a Nothing.  If the argument is Nothing, return Nothing if `value` is non-empty, or false if `value` is empty.

name: insert
description: Adds a value to this set.

name: union
description: Creates a union of the two sets.

name: intersection
description: Creates an intersection of the two sets.

name: difference
description: Computes a set difference.  Returns the set that contains all elements of this set that are not in the other set.

name: First
description: Select the first `count` items.  Selects no items if `count` is less than or equal to 0. Selects all items  if `count` is greater than the length of the input.

name: Last
description: Select the last `count` characters.  Selects no items if `count` is less than or equal to 0. Selects all items  if `count` is greater than the length of the input.

name: While
description: Select elements from the start while the predicate returns `True`.

name: By_Index
description: Selects specific indexes (starting from 0) either as an `Integer` or a `Range`.  If the index or start of the Range is out of bounds, an error is reported. If the end of the Range is out of bounds, all items until the end of the input are selected.  Only ranges with positive step and positive indices are supported. Individual integer indices can be negative which allows for indexing from the end of the collection.

name: Sample
description: Gets a random sample of entries, without repetitions.  If `count` is greater than the length of the input, a random permutation of all elements from the input is selected.

name: Every
description: Gets every Nth entry.

name: default_options
description: It includes all constructors of `Index_Sub_Range` but also `Range`, since the `Index_Sub_Range` type is by default used in sum types containing `Range` too.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert to a display representation of this Index_Sub_Range.

name: resolve_ranges
description: Resolves a vector of ranges or indices into a vector of ranges that fit within a sequence.

name: normalize_ranges
description: Takes a list of descriptors and returns a new one where ranges with non-unitary step have been replaced with series of ranges covering the same set of indices with step equal to 1, and indices have been replaced with single-element ranges.

name: invert_range_selection
description: Inverts the selection determined by the input list of ranges.  The input ranges are assumed to be normalized (i.e. all of them have step equal to 1).

name: sort_and_merge_ranges
description: Returns a new sorted list of ranges where intersecting ranges have been merged.  Empty subranges are discarded.

name: take_helper
description: A helper that implements taking from an arbitrary collection using a set of callbacks.

name: drop_helper
description: A helper that implements dropping from an arbitrary collection using a set of callbacks.

name: Inclusive
description: A bound that includes the value `n`.

name: Exclusive
description: A bound that excludes the value `n`.

name: Inclusive
description: Both the start and end bounds are included.

name: Start_Exclusive
description: The start bound is included, but the end bound is excluded.

name: End_Exclusive
description: The start bound is excluded, but the end bound is included.

name: Exclusive
description: Both the start and end bounds are excluded.

name: Between
description: A type representing an interval over real numbers.

name: new
description: Creates an interval.

name: contains
description: Checks if the interval contains `that`.

name: is_empty
description: Check if this interval is empty.

name: not_empty
description: Check if this interval is not empty.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert to a display representation of this Interval.
Methods for serializing from and to JSON.

name: parse
description: Parse a Text value into a `JS_Object` or an Enso primitive value (like `Text`, `Number`, `Boolean`, `Nothing`), or a `Vector` of values.

name: stringify
description: Serialize an Object to JSON.

name: from_pairs
description: Convert a Vector of Keys and Values to JSON. Keys must be `Text` values.

name: to_display_text
description: Converts the error to a display representation.

name: new
description: Creates a new `JS_Object` from an `ObjectNode`.

name: from_pairs
description: Creates a JS_Object from a list of key-value pairs. Keys must be `Text` values. Values will be recursively converted to JSON serializable as needed.

name: contains_key
description: Returns True iff the objects contains the given `key`.

name: get
description: Get a value for a key of the object, or a default value if that key is not present.

name: at
description: Get a value for a key of the object. If the key is not found, throws a `No_Such_Key` error.

name: field_names
description: Get the keys of the object.

name: map
description: Maps a function over each value in this object

name: map_with_key
description: Maps a function over each field-value pair in the object.

name: length
description: Gets the number of keys in the object.

name: is_empty
description: Returns True if the JS_Object is empty, i.e., does not have any entries.

name: not_empty
description: Returns True if the JS_Object is not empty, i.e., has at least one entry.

name: to_vector
description: Convert the object to a Vector of Pairs.

name: to_js_object
description: Convert the object to a JS_Object.

name: to_text
description: Convert to a Text.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert JS_Object to a friendly string.

name: to_json
description: Convert to a JSON representation.

name: to_default_visualization_data
description: Transform the vector into text for displaying as part of its default visualization.

name: into
description: Creates an Enso object from the JS_Object.

name: set_value
description: Modify a field of a JSON object, returning a new updated object.

name: read_json_node
description: Read a JsonNode to an Enso type

name: read_json_array
description: Read a JsonNode to a Vector

name: to_json_node
description: Convert a value to a JsonNode

name: make_field_name_selector
description: Make a field name selector

name: render
description: Render the JS_Object to Text with truncated depth.

name: make_enso
description: Internal function ensuring that a Jackson object is presented appropriately to Enso.

name: Nil
description: The type that indicates the end of a cons list.

name: Cons
description: A cons cell for a cons list.

name: length
description: Computes the number of elements in the list.
remarks: ! Computational Complexity    Note that this is a linear operation requiring O(n) time.

name: at
description: Gets an element from the list at a specified index (0-based).
remarks: ! Computational Complexity    Note that this is a linear operation requiring O(n) time.

name: get
description: Gets an element from the list at a specified index (0-based). If the index is invalid then `if_missing` is returned.
remarks: ! Computational Complexity    Note that this is a linear operation requiring O(n) time.

name: fold
description:
Combines all the elements of the list, by iteratively applying the passed function with next elements of the list. 

 In general, the result of     (Cons l0 <| Cons l1 <| ... <| Cons ln) . fold init f is the same as     f (...(f (f init l0) l1)...) ln

name: reduce
description: Combines all the elements of a non-empty list using a binary operation. If the list is empty, it returns `if_empty`.

name: any
description: Checks whether any element of the list matches the given condition.

name: all
description: Checks whether a condition holds for all elements in this list.

name: contains
description: Checks whether this list contains a given value as an element.

name: is_empty
description: Checks if this list is empty.

name: not_empty
description: Checks if the list is not empty.

name: filter
description: Selects all elements of this list which satisfy a condition.

name: partition
description: Partitions the list into lists of elements which satisfy a given condition and ones that do not.  Returns a `Pair` whose `first` element is the list of elements satisfying the predicate and the `second` element is a list of elements which did not satisfy it.  The relative order of elements kept in each returned list is the same as in the input.

name: map
description: Applies a function to each element of the list, returning the list of results.

name: each
description:
Applies a function to each element of the list. 

 Unlike `map`, this method does not return the individual results, therefore it is only useful for side-effecting computations.  If the function returns a dataflow error, the error is converted to a panic and thrown immediately stopping further processing.

name: reverse
description: Reverses the list, returning a list with the same elements, but in the opposite order.

name: drop_start
description: Creates a new list with the first `count` elements at the start of `self` removed.

name: take_start
description: Creates a new list consisting of the first `count` elements at the start of `self`.

name: init
description: Get all elements from the list except the last.

name: last
description: Get the last element of the list.

name: first
description: Get the first element from the list.

name: second
description: Get the second element from the list.

name: head
description: Get the first element from the list.

name: tail
description: Get all elements from the list except the first.

name: to_vector
description: Convert this list to a vector with the same elements.

name: to_text
description: Generates a human-readable text representation of the list.

name: find
description: Returns the first element of the list that satisfies the condition or if no elements of the list satisfy the predicate, returns `if_missing`.

name: index_of
description: Returns the index of the element in the list. Returns Nothing if the element is not found.

name: last_index_of
description: Returns the last index of the element in the list. Returns Nothing if the element is not found.

name: find_node_from_start
description: Given a positive index and a list, returns the node.

name: find_node_from_end
description: Given a negative index and a list, returns the node that is represented and the index of it.

name: Value
description: A type representing a locale.

name: new
description: Construct a new locale.

name: from_java
description: Convert a java locale to an Enso locale.

name: from_language_tag
description: Returns the locale specified by the provided IETF BCP47 language tag string.
remarks: ? Language Tag Syntax   If the specified language tag contains any ill-formed subtags, the first   such subtag and all following subtags are ignored.    The following conversions are performed:   - The language code "und" is mapped to language "".   - The language codes "he", "yi", and "id" are mapped to "iw", "ji", and     "in" respectively.   - The portion of a private use subtag prefixed by "lvariant", if any, is     removed and appended to the variant field in the result locale (without     case normalization).   - When the languageTag argument contains an extlang subtag, the first such     subtag is used as the language, and the primary language subtag and other     extlang subtags are ignored.   - Case is normalized except for variant tags, which are left unchanged.     Language is normalized to lower case, script to title case, country to     upper case, and extensions to lower case.   - If, after processing, the locale would exactly match either ja_JP_JP or     th_TH_TH with no extensions, the appropriate extensions are added.    This implements the 'Language-Tag' production of BCP47, and so supports   grandfathered (regular and irregular) as well as private use language tags.

name: default
description: The default locale.  The default locale is a locale that does not specify any language, country, or variant and is used as the language/country-neutral setting for locale sensitive operations.

name: bangladesh
description: A locale representing Bangladesh.

name: brazil
description: A locale representing Brazil.

name: canada_english
description: A locale representing Canada with language English.

name: canada_french
description: A locale representing Canada with language French.

name: china
description: A locale representing the PRC.

name: france
description: A locale representing France.

name: germany
description: A locale representing Germany.

name: india_hindi
description: A locale representing India with language Hindi.

name: india_english
description: A locale representing India with language English.

name: indonesia
description: A locale representing Indonesia.

name: italy
description: A locale representing Italy.

name: japan
description: A locale representing Japan.

name: mexico
description: A locale representing Mexico.

name: nigeria
description: A locale representing Nigeria.

name: pakistan_urdu
description: A locale representing paksitan with language Urdu.

name: pakistan_english
description: A locale representing paksitan with language English.

name: poland
description: A locale representing Poland.

name: russia
description: A locale representing Russia.

name: south_korea
description: A locale representing South Korea.

name: uk
description: A locale representing the UK.

name: us
description: A locale representing the United States.

name: default_widget
description: Gets the default drop down option for Locale.

name: language
description: Gets the language from the locale.

name: country
description: Gets the country from the locale.

name: variant
description: Gets the variant from the locale.

name: display_language
description: Gets a representation of the language in the locale that can be shown to the user.

name: display_country
description: Gets a representation of the country in the locale that can be shown to the user.

name: display_variant
description: Gets a representation of the variant in the locale that can be shown to the user.

name: to_text
description: Converts the locale to text.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert Locale to a friendly string.
Deprecate place holder for the Map type.

name: empty
description: DEPRECATED Use Dictionary.empty instead.

name: singleton
description: DEPRECATED Use Dictionary.singleton instead.

name: from_keys_and_values
description: DEPRECATED Use Dictionary.from_keys_and_values instead.

name: from_vector
description: DEPRECATED Use Dictionary.from_vector instead.

name: None
description: No contained value.

name: Some
description: A value.

name: maybe
description: Applies the provided function to the contained value if it exists, otherwise returning the provided default value.

name: is_some
description: Check if the maybe value is `Some`.

name: is_none
description: Check if the maybe value is `None`.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert Maybe to a friendly string.
The root type of the Enso numeric hierarchy.  If a Number is expected, then the program can provide either a Float or an Integer in its place.

name: positive_infinity
description: A constant holding the floating-point positive infinity.

name: negative_infinity
description: A constant holding the floating-point negative infinity.

name: nan
description: A constant holding the floating-point Not-a-Number value.

Adds two arbitrary numbers. 

 Addition in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.
Subtract an arbitrary number from this.

Multiply two arbitrary numbers. 

 Multiplication in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.

Divides an this by an arbitrary number. 

 Division in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.
Compute the result of raising this to the power that.

name: asin
description: Computes the inverse of the sine function  Selects a value in the -pi/2 through pi/2 range.

name: acos
description: Computes the inverse of the cosine function.  Selects a value in the -pi/2 through pi/2 range.

name: atan
description: Computes the inverse of the tangent function.  Selects a value in the -pi/2 through pi/2 range.

name: atan_2
description:
Computes the argument (angle) in the conversion from cartesian to polar coordinates, taking `self` as the x coordinate. 

 The returned angle is in the -pi through pi range.

name: sin
description: Computes the sine function.

name: cos
description: Computes the cosine function.

name: tan
description: Computes the tangent function.

name: sinh
description: Computes the hyperbolic sine function.

name: cosh
description: Computes the hyperbolic cosine function.

name: tanh
description: Computes the hyperbolic tangent function.

name: exp
description: Computes the exponential function, raising Euler's number `r` to the power of `self`.

name: ln
description: Computes the natural logarithm function.

name: sqrt
description: Computes the square root of `self`.

name: log
description: Computes the `base`-log of `self`.

name: format
description: Converts a numeric value to a string, using the Java DecimalFormat formatter.

name: equals
description: Checks equality of numbers, using an `epsilon` value.

name: min
description: Returns the smaller value of `self` and `that`.
remarks: ? Math.min or Number.min   While we provide the min method on `Number`, we find it more intuitive to   write `Math.min a b` rather than `a.min b`. To that end, we recommend using   the first style.

name: max
description: Returns the larger value of `self` and `that`.
remarks: ? Math.max or Number.max   While we provide the max method on `Number`, we find it more intuitive to   write `Math.max a b` rather than `a.max b`. To that end, we recommend using   the first style.

name: is_nan
description: Checks if the given number is the floating-point Not-a-Number value.  This is needed, because the NaN value will return `False` even when being compared with itself, so `x == Number.nan` would not work.

name: is_infinite
description: Checks if the given number is infinite.

name: is_finite
description: Checks if the given number is finite, i.e. not infinite nor NaN.

name: signum
description: Returns the sign of the number.
Float is the type of float numbers in Enso.
remarks: ? Representation   Enso's float numbers are represented as IEEE754 double-precision   floating point numbers.

name: parse
description: Parses a string into a `Float`, returning a `Number_Parse_Error` if the text does not represent a valid `Float`.

name: max_value
description: Maximum representable positive value, from the underlying Java double type.  The absolute-value-largest representable negative value is `-max_value`.

name: min_value
description: Minimum representable positive value, from the underlying Java double type.

Adds a float and an arbitrary number. 

 Addition in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.
Subtract an arbitrary number from this.

Multiply a float by an arbitrary number. 

 Multiplication in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.

Divides a float by an arbitrary number. 

 Division in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.

Computes the remainder when dividing this by that. 

 Modulus in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.
remarks: ? Negative Arguments    When the first argument to `%` is negative, the result will also be   negative.

description: Compute the result of raising this to the power that.
Checks if this is greater than that.
Checks if this is greater than or equal to that.
Checks if this is less than that.
Checks if this is less than or equal to that.

name: abs
description: Computes the absolute value of this.  The absolute value of a positive number is itself, while the absolute value of a negative number is that number multiplied by -1.

name: ceil
description: Computes the nearest integer equal to or above this number.  This method provides a means of converting a Float to an Integer.

name: floor
description: Computes the nearest integer equal to or below this number.  This method provides a means of converting a Float to an Integer.

name: truncate
description: Truncate a floating-point number to an integer by dropping the fractional part. This is equivalent to "round-toward-zero".

name: round
description: Round to a specified number of decimal places.  By default, rounding uses "symmetric round-half-up", also known as "half-up." If use_bankers=True, then it uses "round-half-even", also known as "banker's rounding".  If `decimal_places` > 0, `round` returns a `Float`; otherwise, it returns an `Integer`.  If the argument is `NaN` or `+/-Inf`, an `Arithmetic_Error` error is thrown.
remarks: ? Negative decimal place counts   Rounding to `n` digits can be thought of as "rounding to the nearest   multiple of 10^(-n)". For negative decimal counts, this results in   rounding to the nearest positive integer power of 10.

name: negate
description: Compute the negation of this.

name: to_float
description: Convert this to a float.  This is a no-op on floats, but is provided for completeness of the Enso Number API.

name: to_decimal
description: Convert this to a `Decimal`.
Integer is the type of integral numbers in Enso. They are of unbounded size and can grow as large as necessary.
remarks:
? Representation   For certain operations (such as bitwise logic), the underlying   representation of the number matters. Enso Integers are represented as   signed 2's complement numbers. 

? Performance   Integers that fit into 64 bits are represented in memory as 64 bits.   This means that operations on them achieve excellent performance. Once   the integer grows beyond being able to fit in 64 bits, performance will   degrade.

name: parse
description: Parses a textual representation of an integer into an integer number, returning a `Number_Parse_Error` if the text does not represent a valid integer.

Adds an integer and an arbitrary number. 

 Addition in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.
Subtract an arbitrary number from this.

Multiply an integer by an arbitrary number. 

 Multiplication in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.

Divides an integer by an arbitrary number. 

 Division in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.

Computes the remainder when dividing this by that. 

 Modulus in Enso will undergo automatic conversions such that you need not convert between Integer and Float manually.  Returns an error if the shift amount exceeds 2^32.
remarks: ? Negative Arguments    When the first argument to `%` is negative, the result will also be   negative.

description: Compute the result of raising this to the power that.
Checks if this is greater than that.
Checks if this is greater than or equal to that.
Checks if this is less than that.
Checks if this is less than or equal to that.

name: abs
description: Computes the absolute value of this.  The absolute value of a positive number is itself, while the absolute value of a negative number is that number multiplied by -1.

name: ceil
description: Computes the nearest integer above this integer.  This is a no-op on integers but is provided for completeness of the Enso number API.

name: div
description:
Computes the integer division of this by that. 

 Integer division rounds down to the nearest integer.  Returns an error if `that` is zero.

name: floor
description: Computes the nearest integer below this integer.  This is a no-op on integers but is provided for completeness of the Enso number API.

name: truncate
description: Truncate an `Integer` to an `Integer`, i.e. returns its argument. For compatibility with `Float.truncate`.

name: round
description: Round to a specified number of decimal places.  For integers, rounding to 0 or more decimal places simply returns the argument. For negative decimal places, see below.  By default, rounding uses "symmetric round-half-up", also known as "half-up." If use_bankers=True, then it uses "round-half-even", also known as "banker's rounding".
remarks: ? Negative decimal place counts   Rounding to `n` digits can be thought of as "rounding to the nearest   multiple of 10^(-n)". For negative decimal counts, this results in   rounding to the nearest positive integer power of 10.

name: negate
description: Compute the negation of this.

name: to_float
description: Convert this to a float.

name: to_decimal
description: Convert this to a `Decimal`.

name: bit_and
description:
Computes the bitwise and (conjunction) operation between this and that. 

 Bitwise and computes the logical conjunction of the corresponding pairs of bits in the operands.

name: bit_not
description: Computes the bitewise compliment of this.  The bitwise compliment negates the value of each bit in the operand.

name: bit_or
description:
Computes the bitwise or (disjunction) operation between this and that. 

 Bitwise or computes the logical disjunction of the pairs of corresponding bits in the operands.

name: bit_xor
description:
Computes the bitwise exclusive or between this and that. 

 Bitwise exclusive or computes the exclusive or of the pairs of corresponding bits in the operands.

name: bit_shift
description: Shifts the bits of this by the amount that.  Left-shifts fill the new bits with zeroes, while right-shifts perform sign extension.  Returns an error if the shift amount exceeds 2^32.

name: bit_shift_l
description: Performs a bitwise left-shift on the number.  Left-shifts fill the new bits with zeroes, while right-shifts perform sign extension.  Returns an error if the shift amount exceeds 2^32.

name: bit_shift_r
description: Performs a bitwise right-shift on the number.  Left-shifts fill the new bits with zeroes, while right-shifts perform sign extension.  Returns an error if the shift amount exceeds 2^32.

name: to_display_text
description: Pretty print the syntax error.

name: Value
description: This constructor should not be used by user code as it can be used to break the invariants. Instead, this type should only be created by `new` or conversions.

name: new
description: Constructor to create a `Positive_Integer` from an `Integer` - checking if it satisfies the condition. User code should prefer the `Positive_Integer.from` conversion.

name: from
description: Allows to create a `Positive_Integer` from an `Integer`. It will throw `Illegal_Argument` if the provided integer is not positive.

name: new
description: Creates new opaque `Comparable` instance for given `value` and a `Comparator` with two static methods what work on the type `T` of the provided `value`:  ``` type Comparator T     compare : T -> T -> (Ordering|Nothing ! Incomparable_Values)     hash : T -> Integer ```  Typically used inside of `Comparable.from` method definition.

name: Less

name: Equal
description: A representation that the first value orders as equal to the second.

name: Greater

name: hash

name: from_sign
description: Converts a sign-based representation of ordering to Enso's native ordering.

name: to_sign
description: Converts the ordering to the signed notion of ordering based on integers.

name: and_then
description: A lexicographical comparison.

name: Value

name: new
description: Create a new Pair from two elements.

name: last

name: map

name: length

name: to_vector
description: Returns the pair as a Vector.

name: at
description: Gets an element from the pair at a specified index (0-based).

name: get
description: Gets an element from the pair at a specified index (0-based). If the index is invalid then `if_missing` is returned.

name: any
description: Checks whether a predicate holds for at least one element of this pair.

name: all
description: Checks whether a predicate holds for all elements in this pair.

name: contains
description: Checks whether this pair contains a given value as an element.

name: find
description: Returns the first element of the pair that satisfies the predicate or if no elements satisfy the predicate, returns `if_missing`.

name: index_of
description: Returns the index of an element in the pair. Returns Nothing if the element is not found.

name: last_index_of
description: Returns the last index of an element in the pair. Returns Nothing if the element is not found.

name: fold
description: Combines all the elements of the pair, by iteratively applying the passed function with next elements of the pair.

name: reduce
description: Combines all the elements of the pair using a binary operation.

name: reverse
description: Reverses the pair, returning a pair with the same elements, but in the opposite order.

name: each
description: Applies a function to each element of the pair.  Unlike `map`, this method does not return the individual results, therefore it is only useful for side-effecting computations.  If the function returns a dataflow error, the error is converted to a panic and thrown immediately stopping further processing.

name: to_display_text
description: Convert to a display representation of this Pair.

name: pair
description: Create a new Pair from two elements.

name: Between
description: A representation of a right-exclusive range of integer values.

name: new
description: Create a representation of a right-exclusive range of integer values.

name: with_step
description: Creates a copy of this range with a changed step.

name: first
description: Returns the first element that is included within the range.  It will raise `Index_Out_Of_Bounds` if the range is empty.

name: second
description: Returns the second element that is included within the range.  It will raise `Index_Out_Of_Bounds` if the range has less than two elements.

name: last
description: Returns the last element that is included within the range.  It will raise `Index_Out_Of_Bounds` if the range is empty.

name: length
description: Get the number of elements in the range.

name: at
description: Gets an element from the Range at a specified index (0-based).

name: get
description: Gets an element from the Range at a specified index (0-based). If the index is invalid then `if_missing` is returned.

name: is_empty
description: Checks if this range is empty.

name: not_empty
description: Checks if this range is not empty.

name: map
description: Applies a function to each element in the range, producing a vector of results.

name: filter
description: Returns a vector of all elements of this range which satisfy a condition.

name: partition
description: Partitions the range into `Vector`s of elements which satisfy a given condition and ones that do not.  Returns a `Pair` whose `first` element is the `Vector` of elements satisfying the predicate and the `second` element is a `Vector` of elements which did not satisfy it.  The relative order of elements kept in each returned list is the same as in the input.

name: each
description: Applies a function for each element in the range.  This method does not return the results, so it is only useful for performing computations with side-effects.  If the function returns a dataflow error, the error is converted to a panic and thrown immediately stopping further processing.

name: each_propagate
description: Executes a function for each element in the range. Exits early if the body produces an `Error`.

name: fold
description:
Combines all the elements of the range, by iteratively applying the passed function with next elements of the range. 

 In general, the result of     Range start end step . fold init f is the same as     f (...(f (f init start) start+step)...) last

name: running_fold
description: Combines all the elements of the range, by iteratively applying the passed function with the next element of the range. After each step the value is stored resulting in a new Vector of the same size as self.
