name: read
description: Execute the query and load the results into memory as a Table.
remarks: ? Side Effects    Note that the `read` method is running without restrictions when the   output context is disabled, but it can technically cause side effects,   if it is provided with a DML query. Usually it is preferred to use   `execute_update` for DML queries, or if they are supposed to return   results, the `read` should be wrapped in an execution context check.

name: create_table
description: Creates a new empty table in the database and returns a query referencing the new table.
remarks: ? Dry Run if Output disabled    If performing output actions is disabled, only a dry run is performed   and no permanent changes occur. The operation will test for errors   (like missing columns) and if successful, return a temporary table with   a `Dry_Run_Operation` warning attached.

name: execute_update

name: prepare_metadata_for_period
description: Prepares metadata for an operation taking a date/time period and checks if the given period is supported.

name: if_replace_params_supports
description: Returns true if the `replace` parameters are supported by this backend.

name: should_check_table_integrity_at_beginning_of_transaction
description: In Snowflake we need to create tables outside of transactions. However, currently we decide to opt-out of the integrity check for performance reasons - there is too much overhead to each query. The check would fail extremely rarely so it currently does not seem worth the cost. We can revisit this choice in the future.

name: custom_build_aggregate
description: We need custom handling for First and Last aggregations, because in Snowflake the `FIRST_VALUE` and `LAST_VALUE` functions in Snowflake are purely window functions - they cannot be directly used in aggregate queries.  If tried to be used inside of a group by, it yields an error:     Window function [FIRST_VALUE(T.A) OVER (PARTITION BY T.B ORDER BY T.C ASC NULLS LAST)] may not appear inside an aggregate function.

name: snowflake
description: The dialect of Snowflake databases.

name: replace_with_zero_if_null
description: A helper needed because Snowflake's aggregators return NULL if there were no rows. But for aggregators like COUNT we prefer to return 0 in such cases.

name: replace_null_with_marker
description: A helper function that coalesces a NULL column replacing it with a marker value that is expected to not be present in real world data. It is sometimes needed when we want to count distinct values in a column that contains NULLs and still include the rows containing NULLs. The columns are converted to VARIANT type because of that, which may incur some overhead. But there seems to be no other reliable way to handle this for columns like numeric where no non-NULL value exists that can be guaranteed to be unused.

name: make_row_number_in_group
description: A helper for `lookup_and_replace`, and perhaps other operation. It creates an expression that returns a row number within a group. This is a specialization for Snowflake that adds a dummy ORDER BY clause to satisfy its compiler.

name: make_runtime_error_op
description: The RUNTIME_ERROR operation should allow the query to compile fine and it will not prevent it from running if the branch including this operation is not taken. But if the branch is computed, it should ensure the query fails.  This query never returns a value, so its type should be polymorphic. However, that is not possible - so currently it just 'pretends' that it would return a Boolean - because that is the type we expect in the use-case. This can be altered if needed.  It takes a variable as the second argument. It can be any value that is not statically known - this ensure that the optimizer will not be able to pre-compute the expression too early (which could make the query fail spuriously). See `make_invariant_check` in `Lookup_Query_Helper` for an example.

name: make_custom_cast
description: Returns a custom cast expression if it is needed for a specific pair of types, or Nothing if the default cast is sufficient.

name: infer_return_type
description: The Snowflake_Type_Mapping always relies on the return type determined by the database backend.

name: prepare_type_overrides
description: We want to respect any overriding references, but references that rely on computing the type by the database are resolved to Nothing to just rely on the `ResultSet` metadata and decrease overhead.

name: make_column_fetcher
description: Creates a `Column_Fetcher` used to fetch data from a result set and build an in-memory column from it, based on the given column type.

name: max_length
description: This is the maximum size that JDBC driver reports for 'unbounded' types in Snowflake.

name: smart_integer_fetcher
description: A fetcher for Snowflake Decimal integer columns. Integer columns in Snowflake are represented as `NUMBER(38, 0)`, meaning there is no separate Integer type.  In Enso, using `Decimal` values incurs a significant overhead. Thus, when fetching such an integer column from Snowflake, we try to first fetch it as lightweight `Integer` and only fall back to `Decimal` if needed.

name: integer_type
description: The actual SQL type that Snowflake uses for all integer types.

name: Value
description: A Snowflake database connection.

name: create
description: Creates a Snowflake connection based on a URL and properties.

name: close
description: Closes the connection releasing the underlying database resources immediately instead of waiting for them to be automatically released.  The connection is not usable afterwards.

name: warehouses
description: Returns the list of warehouses for the connection.

name: warehouse
description: Returns the name of the current warehouse.

name: set_warehouse
description: Returns a new Connection with the specified database set as default.

name: databases
description: Returns the list of databases (or catalogs) for the connection.

name: database
description: Returns the name of the current database (or catalog).

name: set_database
description: Returns a new Connection with the specified database set as default.

name: schemas
description: Returns the list of schemas for the connection within the current database (or catalog).

name: schema
description: Returns the name of the current schema.

name: set_schema
description: Returns a new Connection with the specified schema set as default.

name: table_types
description: Gets a list of the table types.

name: tables
description: Returns a materialized Table of all the matching views and tables.
remarks: ? Temporary Tables    Note that the temporary tables may be created in a different schema   than the current one, so take this into account when filtering by schema.

name: query
description: Set up a query returning a Table object, which can be used to work with data within the database or load it into memory.

name: read
description: Execute the query and load the results into memory as a Table.
remarks: ? Side Effects    Note that the `read` method is running without restrictions when the   output context is disabled, but it can technically cause side effects,   if it is provided with a DML query. Usually it is preferred to use   `execute_update` for DML queries, or if they are supposed to return   results, the `read` should be wrapped in an execution context check.

name: create_table
description: Creates a new empty table in the database and returns a query referencing the new table.
remarks: ? Dry Run if Output disabled    If performing output actions is disabled, only a dry run is performed   and no permanent changes occur. The operation will test for errors   (like missing columns) and if successful, return a temporary table with   a `Dry_Run_Operation` warning attached.

name: execute_update
description: Executes a raw update query. If the query was inserting, updating or deleting rows, the number of affected rows is returned; otherwise it returns 0 for other types of queries (like creating or altering tables).

name: execute
description: Executes a raw query. If the query was inserting, updating or deleting rows, the number of affected rows is returned; otherwise it returns 0 for other types of queries (like creating or altering tables).

name: dialect
description: Access the dialect.

name: jdbc_connection
description: Access the underlying JDBC connection.

name: drop_table
description: Drops a table.

name: truncate_table
description: Removes all rows from a table.

name: base_connection
description: Returns the base `Connection` instance.  Used, so that all internal helper functions do not need to be replicated on the 'subclasses'.

name: save_as_data_link
description: Creates a Data Link that will open the same connection.

name: to_js_object
description: Converts this value to a JSON serializable object.

name: to_vector
description: Return the iterator values as a `Vector`.

name: align_sequence_only
description: Aligns this conversion depending on if we want to only expand sequences or all kinds of objects.  If `sequence_only` is `False` or the conversion reports `is_sequence=True`, no changes are made. However, `sequence_only` is `True` and the conversion reports `is_sequence=False`, the conversion is replaced with a single row - same as the `Any` fallback.

name: get
description: Return the key of the pair.

name: Delimited
description: Read delimited files such as CSVs into a Table.  When reading this format, the following problems may occur: - If a row does not match the first row's column count, the function   raises an `Invalid_Row`. - If an empty file is passed, an `Empty_File_Error` is thrown. - If a quote is opened and never closed, a `File_Error.Corrupted_Format`   error is raised.

name: resolve
description: Resolve an unresolved constructor to the actual type.

name: for_read
description: If the File_Format supports reading from the file, return a configured instance.

name: for_file_write
description: If this File_Format should be used for writing to that file, return a configured instance.

name: read
description: Implements the `File.read` for this `File_Format`

name: read_stream
description: Implements decoding the format from a stream.

name: write_table
description: Implements the `Table.write` for this `File_Format`.

name: clone
description: Clone the instance with some properties overridden.

name: with_quotes
description: Create a clone of this with specified quoting settings.

name: without_quotes
description: Create a clone of this with specified quoting settings.

name: with_headers
description: Create a clone of this with first row treated as header.

name: without_headers
description: Create a clone of this where the first row is treated as data, not a header.

name: with_parsing
description: Create a clone of this with value parsing.  A custom `Data_Formatter` can be provided to customize parser options.

name: without_parsing
description: Create a clone of this without value parsing.

name: with_line_endings
description: Creates a clone of this with a changed line ending style.

name: with_comments
description: Creates a clone of this with comment parsing enabled.

name: without_comments
description: Creates a clone of this with comment parsing disabled.

name: from
description: Constructs a `Delimited` instance from JSON.

name: Drop_Invalid_Rows
description: Rows that contain too few or too many columns are dropped.

name: Keep_Invalid_Rows
description: Rows that contain too few or too many columns are kept  - If a row has too few columns, the missing columns are filled with `Nothing`. - If it has too many, the extra columns are dropped.

name: Add_Extra_Columns
description: Rows that contain more columns than expected are kept, and the extra columns are added.  - If a row has too few columns, the missing columns are filled with `Nothing`. - If it has too many, the extra columns are kept. The previous rows that   had less columns are filled with `Nothing`.

name: from
description: A conversion for backward compatibility.

name: No_Quotes
description: Do not quote any values or parse quotes when reading a `Delimited` file.  In write mode, values are not quoted even if this would result in an invalid file.

name: With_Quotes
description: Specifies the style of quotes when reading or writing a `Delimited` file.
remarks: ! Quote Character    The quote and escape characters must consist of exactly one code-point   (i.e. it can be only one character and complex characters like emojis   may not be used).

name: Always_Quote
description: Always quote text values when reading or writing a `Delimited` file.
remarks: ! Quote Character    The quote and escape characters must consist of exactly one code-point   (i.e. it can be only one character and complex characters like emojis   may not be used).

name: Workbook
description: Reads an Excel file as a connection to an `Excel_Workbook`.

name: Sheet

name: Range

name: resolve

name: for_file_write

name: read_stream

name: write_table
description: Implements the `Table.write` for this `File_Format`.  Depending on the `section` will control where to write. - If `Excel_Section.Workbook` (the default), the `table` will be written   to a new sheet in the workbook named `Sheet<n>` where n is the first   integer >1 that is not already used as a sheet name. If too many sheets   are present an `Illegal_Argument` error will be thrown. - If `Excel_Section.Worksheet`, the `table` will be written to the   specified sheet (either adding or replacing). - If `Excel_Section.Cell_Range`, the `table` will be written to the   specified range.

name: should_treat_as_xls_format

name: xls_format_from_metadata

name: as_section

name: Value

name: is_valid_row

name: bottom_row

name: _resolve_return_as_compatibility
description: A helper method that ensures that we can take the new `Return_As_Table` type as well as the deprecated `Return_As` type, together with autoscoping. With autoscoping, the `As_Merged_Table` constructor is ambiguous, so plain autoscoping would not work and we do some workarounds to make it work. In case of the ambiguity, the new-style `Return_As_Table.As_Merged_Table` variant is preferred.

name: parse_to_table
description: Converts a Text into a Table using a regular expression pattern.  Each match becomes a row in the table.  If there are no marked groups, there will be a single column with the whole content of the match. Otherwise, each group becomes a column (with the column name taken from the group name if the group is named in the regex).  For details on Enso's Regex syntax, see the [Help Documentation](https://help.enso.org/docs/using-enso/regular-expressions).
remarks: ? Column Names  If there are no marked groups, the new column will be named `Column`. If the marked groups are named, the names will be used otherwise the column will be named `Column <N>` where `N` is the number of the marked group. (Group 0 is not included.)

name: rename_columns_if_needed
description: If the table already contains a column called `name` it will be renamed to a unique name, so that a new column with this name can be added.
A marker for missing columns during resolution.

name: prepare_aggregate_columns
description: Prepares an aggregation input for further processing: - resolves the column descriptors, reporting any issues, - ensures that the output names are unique, - finds the key columns.

name: default_aggregate_column_name
description: Defines the default name of an `Aggregate_Column`.  To be used when `as` is `Nothing`.  Assumes that the `Aggregate_Column` is resolved. You may need to transform it with `resolve_aggregate` first.

name: all_same_column
description: Utility function to check if all aggregates are operating on the same source column.

name: resolve_aggregate
description: Returns a copy of this aggregate where all column descriptors (names, indices or column references potentially from a different table) are replaced with column references from the provided table.  It also verifies that the columns have the right types.  `Sort_Column`s are replaced with column references of matched columns coming from the provided table.  This preprocess step is required by some helper function, to avoid having to pass the table reference and resolve the column descriptors all the time.  If some columns cannot be resolved, `Nothing` is returned. Any issues are reported to the `Problem_Builder`.

name: java_aggregator
description: Creates a Java Aggregator for the Aggregate_Column

name: check_cast_compatibility
description: Checks if one type can be cast into another and returns a dataflow error explaining the situation if not.

name: make_value_formatter_for_value_type
description: Create a formatter for the specified `Value_Type`.

name: make_value_formatter
description: Create a formatter for the given format string. The `value` parameter has to have a `format` method that takes a format and locale.

name: make_boolean_formatter
description: Create a `Boolean` formatter that takes the format string as the second parameter.

name: handle_illegal_argument_exception
description: Rethrow a Java IllegalArgumentException as an Illegal_Argument.

name: in_memory
description: A `Column_Naming_Helper` for the in-memory backend - having no length limits.

name: create_unique_name_strategy
description: Creates a `Unique_Name_Strategy` that will generate names keeping the column naming limitations in mind.

name: ensure_name_is_valid
description: Checks if the name is valid and runs the action, otherwise raises an error.

name: validate_many_column_names
description: Checks if the names are valid and runs the action, otherwise raises an error.

name: sanitize_name
description: Ensures that the name does not contain the null character.

name: check_ambiguity
description: Checks if the new name is unambiguously different from the existing ones. In particular, it is used for case-insensitive backends to ensure that there are no two columns that while not equal, are equal ignoring case - which could introduce problems.

name: binary_operation_name
description: Generates a column name for a binary operation.

name: function_name
description: Generates a column name for a function-like transformation.

name: to_expression_text
description: Serializes a given object into an expression-like text approximation. Note that it may not necessarily be a valid expression, it just tries to be similar to one. In many cases it will be valid, but it is not a guarantee.  For columns, it will return its name wrapped in `[` and `]`. For other objects, it will return its pretty-printed representation.

name: concat
description: Concatenates a vector of texts that are meant to make a single column name, ensuring it will fit within the limit.  It may truncate the whole text or also truncate individual parts to try to display every part.

name: make_temp_column_name
description: Create a column called "temp", possibly renamed.

name: map_over_storage
description: Map a text-returning function over the column values, using Storage directly. The output column has the same name as the input.

name: map_2_over_storage
description: Map a text-returning function over the values of two columns, using Storage directly. The output column has the same name as the first input column. `skip_nothing` applies to the first input to the function, not both inputs.

name: make_date_part_function
description: Common logic for `Column.date_part`.

name: Existing
description: Represents the headers found in the file.

name: None
description: Indicates that the file exists but no headers have been found, so only positional column matching is possible.  Note that the file may still contain rows that have less or more columns than specified here. This column count is only based on the first row.

name: Value
description: An internal type representing metadata describing the format of a specific Delimited file.

name: read_file
description: Reads a delimited file according to the provided format.

name: read_stream
description: Reads an input stream according to the provided format.

name: read_from_reader
description: Reads data from the provided `Reader` according to the provided format.  The `encoding` parameter is ignored, instead the provided reader should handle any necessary decoding.

name: detect_metadata

name: newline_at_eof
description: Checks if the file has a newline at the end.  Returns the newline sequence if found, `Nothing` otherwise.

name: write_file
description: Writes a delimited file according to the provided format.

name: append_to_file
description: Handles appending to an existing file, ensuring that the columns are matched against the ones already in the file.  If the file does not exist or is empty, it acts like a regular overwrite.

name: write_text
description: Returns a Text value representing the table in the delimited format.

name: write_to_stream
description: Writes to an output stream according to the provided format.

name: write_to_writer
description: Writes data to the provided `Writer` according to the provided format.  The `encoding` parameter is ignored, instead the provided writer should handle any necessary encoding.

name: default_line_separator_for_writing
description: The default line separator used for newly written delimited files, if no specific separator has been set.

name: display_table
description: Renders an ASCII-art representation for a Table from a dataframe that contains a fragment of the underlying data and count of all rows.

name: print_table
description: A helper function for creating an ASCII-art representation of tabular data.

name: pad
description: Ensures that the `txt` has at least `len` characters by appending spaces at the end.

name: ansi_bold
description: Adds ANSI bold escape sequences to text if the feature is enabled.

name: _get_item_as_text
description: Gets a textual representation of the item at position `ix` in `storage`.

name: _normalize_text_for_display
description: Ensures that the text can be safely displayed in a terminal.  If the string contains special characters, it will be wrapped in quotes and the characters escaped. Otherwise, the string is returned as-is.

description: Convert Headers to the correct HeaderBehavior

name: handle_reader

name: read_file
description: Reads an input Excel file according to the provided section.

name: handle_bad_format
description: A helper that handles the Java exceptions reported when a malformed XLS file is opened.

name: handle_bad_format_with_handler
description: A helper that handles the Java exceptions reported when a malformed XLS file is opened.

name: handle_invalid_location
description: A helper that handles the Java exceptions reported when a sheet, range or address is invalid.

name: Worksheet
description: Gets the data from a specific sheet.

name: Cell_Range
description: Gets a specific range (taking either a defined name or external style address) from the workbook. If it is a single cell, it will be treated as the top left cell and will expand right and down to cover the connected cells.

name: write_file
description: Writes a Table to an Excel file.

name: handle_writer
description: Handle and map the Java errors when writing an Excel file

name: expand_to_rows
description:
Expand aggregate values in a column to separate rows.  For each value in the specified column, if it is an aggregate (`Vector`, `Range`, etc.), expand it to multiple rows, duplicating the values in the other columns. 

 The following aggregate values are supported: - `Array` - `Vector` - `List` - `Range` - `Date_Range` - `Pair  Any other values are treated as non-aggregate values, and their rows are kept unchanged.  In in-memory tables, it is permitted to mix values of different types.

name: fan_out_to_columns
description: Transform a table by transforming a column into a set of columns. Takes a function that maps a single element of the input column to a vector of output values. The original column is replaced by the new columns.

name: fan_out_to_rows
description: Transform a column by applying the given function to the values in the column. The function produces multiple outputs, so each row is duplicated, with each row getting a distinct output value in place of the original input value. The other column values are just duplicated.

name: fan_out_to_rows_and_columns
description: Transform a column by applying the given function to the values in the column. The function returns a `Vector` of `Vectors`. Each inner vector turns into multiple new columns in a single row. Each inner vector within the outer vector produces an output row, so each row is duplicated, with each row getting a distinct set of output values in place of the original input value. The other column values are just duplicated.

name: fan_out_to_rows_and_columns_fixed
description: Inner method for fan_out_to_rows_and_columns where the column names are fixed.

name: fan_out_to_rows_and_columns_dynamic
description: Inner method for fan_out_to_rows_and_columns where the column names are determined by each row.

name: map_columns_to_multiple
description: Map a multi-valued function over a column and return the results as set of output columns.  Returns a Pair of a Vector of Columns and a Vector of problems.

name: rename_new_columns
description: Rename a vector of columns to be unique when added to a table.

name: replace_column_with_columns
description: Replace a single column in a table with new columns. Does not ensure names are unique; that must be done before calling this.

name: maximum
description: Return the maximum value of the vector. Throws Empty_Error if the vector is empty.

name: repeat_each
description: Repeat a computation n times.

name: uniform_length
description: Pad or truncate a vector to be a specified length; if altered, report it as a Column_Count_Mismatch warning.

name: make_filter_column
description: A helper function gathering the common logic that generates a boolean mask from a given source column and a filter condition. It contains logic common for all backends.  It also performs validation and will throw errors if unexpected column types are encountered.

name: warn_on_nothing_in_comparison
description: Attach a warning if the provided value is `Nothing`.

name: warn_on_nothing_in_comparison_vector
description: Attach a warning if the provided value is a `Vector` that contains `Nothing`.

name: make_builder_for_type
description: Note: Value_Type must have an exact representation in Java.

name: translate_problem
description: Convert a Java problem into its Enso equivalent.

name: with_problem_aggregator
description: This is the new preferred way of running Java methods that may report problems.

name: resolve
description: Resolves the columns in the provided join conditions, handling any errors and capturing redundant columns.  Resolution errors are aggregated from all conditions (all found errors are reported instead of only the first one). If there were any errors, `Nothing` will be returned as the conditions indicating that state. Besides, a list of redundant columns from equality joins is aggregated which can be used to deduplicate them.
Cartesian product: each row of the left table is paired with each row of the right table.

name: to_sql
description: Returns the SQL representation of this join kind as text.

name: Key_Column
description: A key column used to correlate rows between the two tables.

name: Keep_Column
description: A column from the base table that is kept as-is.

name: Replace_Column
description: A column that is present in both tables. If the row is matched with a row from the lookup table, the value from the lookup table is used; otherwise the value from the base table is kept.

name: Add_Column
description: A new column added from the lookup table. If the row has no match, it will be `Nothing`.

name: prepare_columns_for_lookup
description: Checks if `key_columns` are present in both tables and returns settings indicating which columns will be updated and which will be added.  It also reports any errors or warnings related to selecting these columns.

name: match_columns
description: A helper that encapsulates the common backend-agnostic logic of matching columns in `Table.union`.  It matches columns according to the provided matching settings and returns a list of column sets to be merged.  Each column set consists of a name of the resulting column and a list of indices for columns in corresponding tables that will be merged to form this result column. The first column index corresponds to the first table in the input and so on. If no column corresponding to a given column set was matched in a particular table, its entry will be contain `Nothing` instead.  The column sets are returned in the order in which the corresponding result columns should appear in the resulting table.  The method assumes at least one table is provided in its input.

name: _build_column_set_by_name
description: Common logic for computing the final result of by-name matching. Once the set of output column names is determined, we compute the `Column_Set` by finding the corresponding column indices in each table (if found).

name: _find_column_counts
description: Returns a map indicating in how many tables did a column with a given name appear.

name: _distinct_columns_in_appearance_order
description: Returns a list of distinct column names, in the order of first appearance, starting from the first table.

name: validate_grouping_columns
description: Checks which column may cause problems in the grouping due to imprecise floating-point values.
An interface for a helper managing limitations of entity names.  It extends the API of the Java counterpart `NamingProperties`.

name: encoded_size
description: Returns the size of the string in the target encoding. It may throw a panic if `size_limit` is `Nothing`.

name: truncate
description: Truncates the string to the given size in the target encoding. It may throw a panic if `size_limit` is `Nothing`.

name: size_limit
description: Returns the maximum size of an entity name in the target encoding, or `Nothing` if there is no limit.

name: is_case_sensitive
description: Specifies if names are case sensitive. If not, names that are equal case insensitively, need to be deduplicated.

name: raise_name_too_long_error
description: Raises a `Name_Too_Long` error for the given name. The implementation may customize the extra message appended to the error explaining the limitations.

name: recover_panics
description: A helper method that recovers panics thrown by `Naming_Properties`. The `Naming_Properties` must throw panics and not dataflow errors to comply with the Java `NamingProperties` interface (handling dataflow errors would complicate the usage). This method allows to recover such panics and turn them into dataflow errors.

name: parse_text_to_table
description: Converts a Text into a Table using a regular expression pattern.  See Text.parse_to_table.

name: is_a_valid_parse_target
description: Checks if the type is a valid argument for `parse`.

name: new
description: Creates a new helper object for aggregating problems to report.

name: build_problemset
description: Returns a vector containing all reported problems, aggregated.

name: attach_problems_after
description: Attaches gathered warnings to the result. Any errors from the `result` take precedence over the ones owned by this builder.

name: attach_problems_before
description: Attaches gathered warnings to the result of the provided computation. If in `Report_Error` mode and there are any problems gathered, the first one will be returned as error without even running the computation.

name: get_problemset_throwing_distinguished_errors
description: Returns the generated problem set if no errors force throwing or throws the first error that is meant to be thrown regardless of problem behavior.

name: raise_no_output_columns_with_cause
description: Raises `No_Output_Columns` error, with cause set to the first problem from this builder (if any were reported).

name: append_to_ref
description: Appends a `Vector` to a `Vector_Builder` stored in a `Ref`.

name: from
description: The fallback strategy for converting a generic object into a table. Custom data types may implement a conversion to override this strategy, like above.

name: _merge_input_and_tables
description: Expands each table from `tables_for_rows` and computes their union, also duplicating the corresponding rows from `input_table`.

name: _unify_metadata
description: Unifies provided metadata tables, knowing that some tables may have no  metadata - in such case we want to insert as many Nothing rows for metadata  as there are rows in the corresponding data table.

name: _inherit_warnings_from_vector
description: Workaround for bug https://github.com/enso-org/enso/issues/11570 TODO: Remove workaround one #11570 is closed.

columns.type: Text | Integer | By_Type | Vector (Text | Integer | By_Type)

name: length
description: Gets the number of rows in the table.

name: at
description: Gets the specified row.

name: split_to_columns
description: Splits a column of text into a set of new columns. See `Table.split_to_columns`.

name: split_to_rows
description: Splits a column of text into a set of new rows. See `Table.split_to_rows`.

name: tokenize_to_columns
description: Tokenizes a column of text into a set of new columns using a regular expression. See `Table.tokenize_to_columns`.

name: tokenize_to_rows
description: Tokenizes a column of text into a set of new rows using a regular expression. See `Table.tokenize_to_rows`.

name: parse_to_columns
description: Converts a Text column into new columns using a regular expression pattern. See `Table.parse_to_columns`.

name: regex_parse_to_vectors
description: Create a parser from a regex to a nested `Vector`. Each match becomes an element of the vector; each group (or the whole match, if there are no groups) becomes an element of the inner vectors.

name: regex_to_column_names
description: Generate column names for the output columns from a regex match. If the regex has no explicit groups, it uses the original column name unchanged; otherwise, it uses the group name if it exists, or the original column name with a number.

name: handle_nothing
description: Wrap a function so that it returns [] if passed Nothing.

name: to_value_type
description: Gets the value type represented by this Java Storage.

name: enso_to_java
description: Convert an Enso value to a Java value before storing it in a Java `Column`. This step is unnecessary for primitive and builtin values, but necessary for values such as `Decimal`/`BigDecimal`.

name: java_to_enso
description: Convert a Java value to an Enso value before returning it to Enso from a Java `Column`.  This step is unnecessary for primitive and builtin values, but necessary for values such as `Decimal`/`BigDecimal`.

name: from_value_type
description: Converts a value type to an in-memory storage type, possibly approximating it to the closest supported type.

name: from_value_type_strict
description: A strict variant of `from_value_type` that expects that we can represent the provided value type exactly.

name: make_builder
description: Creates a column storage builder for the given storage type.

name: get_storage_for_column
description: Helper function for tests to get the storage of a Column

name: Value
description: Helps managing table columns.

name: select_columns
description: A helper function encapsulating shared code for `select_columns` implementations of various Table variants. See the documentation for the Table type for details.  It returns the selected columns. It is the responsibility of each implementation to reconstruct a proper table from the resulting list of columns.

name: select_by_type
description: A helper to returns a set of columns filtered by the type of the column.

name: remove_columns
description: A helper function encapsulating shared code for `remove_columns` implementations of various Table variants. See the documentation for the Table type for details.  It returns the columns which should be kept. It is the responsibility of each implementation to reconstruct a proper table from the resulting list of columns.

name: remove_by_type
description: A helper to returns a set of columns filtering out based on the type of the column.

name: reorder_columns
description: A helper function encapsulating shared code for `reorder_columns` implementations of various Table variants. See the documentation for the Table type for details.  It returns the columns which should be kept. It is the responsibility of each implementation to reconstruct a proper table from the resulting list of columns.

name: select_columns_helper
description: A helper function which selects columns from the table based on the provided selection criteria.

name: resolve_column_or_expression
description: A helper function which selects a single column from the table.  It may allow selection of columns by index, name or computing a derived expression.

name: select_blank_columns_helper
description:
A helper method that gets the columns from the provided table that are completely blank or have some blanks. 

-TODO docs - when: By default, only columns consisting of all blank cells are   selected. If set to Blank_Selector.Any_Cell, columns with one or more blank values are   selected. - treat_nans_as_blank: If `True`, then `Number.nan` is considered as   blank. - invert_selection: If `True`, then the selection is inverted.
An internal marker type for `rename_columns`.

name: No_Types_To_Unify
description: This case is returned if the requested column was missing from _all_ tables, so there were no types to unify. An all-null column should be created.

name: read_name_mapping_from_table
description: A helper function which takes a Table like object and a Table for a name mapping and returns a new Table with the columns renamed according to the mapping.

name: rename_columns
description: A helper function encapsulating shared code for `rename_columns` implementations of various Table variants. See the documentation for the Table type for details.  It takes a list of columns and a mapping, and returns the complete new set of column names which should be applied to the table. It is the responsibility of each implementation to reconstruct a proper table from the resulting list of names.

name: sort_columns
description: A helper function encapsulating shared code for `sort_columns` implementations of various Table variants. See the documentation for the Table type for details.  It takes a list of columns and returns the columns in the new order. It is the responsibility of each implementation to reconstruct a proper table from the resulting list of columns.

name: select_indices_reordering
description: Selects element from the vector based on the given indices.  The elements are returned in the same order as their provided indices.

name: select_indices_preserving_order
description: Selects element from the vector based on the given indices.  The elements are returned in the same order as they appeared in the original vector.

name: is_index_valid
description: Checks if the given index is in the valid range for the provided vector.

name: match_columns
description: A helper method to match columns by name

name: prepare_order_by
description: Resolves the `Sort_Column` selectors and ensures that at least one column was selected.

name: resolve_order_by
description: Resolves the `Sort_Column` selectors and returns a list of elements containing the original selector and the selected column.

name: filter_blank_rows
description: A helper method gathering the common logic for constructing expressions that can filter out blank rows.

name: is_column
description: Checks if the given object implements a Table interface.  Currently, it relies on a hack - it checks if the object has a method `is_table` and if it returns `True`.

name: unify_result_type_for_union
description: A helper method that resolves what should be the result type of a particular column set based on the union settings.

name: replace_columns_with_columns
description: Replace a set of columns in the table with a new set of columns. The old columns must all exist in the table, and the list of new columns must be the same length and have the same names.

name: replace_columns_with_transformed_columns
description: Replace a set of columns in the table with a new set of columns produced by transforming the old columns. The old columns must all exist in the table, and the new columns must all have the same name.

name: duplicate_rows
description: Takes a table and a list of counts and returns a new table with the rows duplicated according to the counts. The vector should have the same number of elements as the number of rows in the table.

name: at
description: Get a column. Column must implement all the expected calculations. This returns a Column, but the type is not known statically because it may be an in-memory or Database column.

name: evaluate_expression
description: Given an expression, create a derived column where each value is the result of evaluating the expression for the row.

name: resolve
description: Resolve a Column_Ref to a Column, keeping any other values as-is.

name: resolve_as_column
description: Resolve a Column_Ref to a Column, converting any other values into a constant column.

name: resolve_condition
description: Transforms a condition, changing any Column_Ref instances into Column instances resolved in this table.

name: set
description: Set a column.

name: column_names
description: Gets a list of column names

name: log
description: Schedules a single telemetry message for sending.

name: make_union
description: The implementation of common logic that is used by `Table.from_union`. The caller should ensure that `tables` contains only `Table` instances or `Nothing`. Each `Nothing` is replaced by a single all-nothing row, not introducing any new columns.  The `tables` vector must contain at least one non-nothing entry.

name: _concat_columns
description: A helper that efficiently concatenates storages of in-memory columns.

name: Value
description: Creates a Unique_Name_Strategy

name: new
description: Creates a new Unique_Name_Strategy instance.  This is a mutable data structure, that allows for creating a collection of columns names and making them unique. It will track any duplicates or invalid names that are passed to it.

name: combine_with_prefix
description: Changes names from the second list so that they do not clash with names from the first list and with each other.  It returns a new list where each new name corresponds to a name from the second list.  It assumes that names on each list are unique within that list and that all of the provided names are already valid. The behavior is unspecified if they are not.  The names are renamed using the following strategy: - if the name does not collide with any name from the first list, it will   always be kept as-is, - if the name collides, we first append the provided prefix, if it is now   unique (looking at the first list and the non-renamed elements of the   second one), we return that, - if the name with the prefix still collides, we append a numeric suffix   (starting with `_1`) to it, increasing the number as many times as   necessary to get a name that will not collide.  Note that non-renamed names from the second list have precedence over elements being renamed, even if they show up on the list later.

name: renames
description: Vector of any duplicates renamed.  Note that this vector will not contain renames where just the second_prefix was added.

name: invalid_names
description: Vector of any invalid names.

name: truncated_names
description: A mapping of original names to their truncated counterpart.

name: make_valid_name
description: Takes a value and converts to a valid (but not necessarily unique) name.

name: make_unique
description: Takes a name and gets a unique version.

name: is_unique
description: Tells if the given name has not yet been encountered.  It does not use up the name - it needs to be marked with `mark_used` if needed.

name: make_all_unique
description: Takes a list of names and gets a list of unique versions.

name: mark_used
description: Takes a list of names and marks them as used, so that any further names clashing with those will have a prefix added.

name: most_specific_value_type
description: Finds the most specific `Value_Type` that can be used to hold the given value.  This method will still prefer default types used in the in-memory backend, so for integers it will return 64-bit integers even if the value could fit in a smaller one; and for Text values variable-length text will be preferred over fixed-length.

name: reconcile_types
description: Finds a type that can fit both a current type and a new type.

name: max_size
description: Reconciles two size parameters. If either of them is `Nothing` (meaning unbounded), returns `Nothing`. If both are bounded, the larger one is returned.

name: find_common_type
description: Finds the most specific value type that will fit all the provided types.

name: find_common_date_types
description: An extra helper function that reconciles Date_Time types with varying timezone setting, as well as Date type, reporting any warnings. It can be used as a fallback after `find_common_type` does not find a simple common type. If non-date types are provided, it will fail by returning `Nothing`. It will not report any warnings in that case. It assumes that the list of `types` is not empty.

name: find_common_numeric_boolean_type
description: An extra helper function that reconciles numeric and boolean types. Unifying Boolean and numeric types is not expected by all operations, but some may want to opt-in to it. This method allows to do so.  If non-numeric or non-boolean types are provided, it will fail by returning `Nothing`.  No warnings are reported, as coercing boolean to integer is harmless, it was just chosen not to be done by default.

name: find_argument_type
description: Finds the type of an argument to a column operation.  If the argument is a column, the type of that column is returned. If it is an Enso value, the smallest `Value_Type` that can fit that value will be returned (but the Database is free to widen it to the closest type that it supports without warning).  Since there is no special type for `Nothing` and `Nothing` technically can fit any nullable type, it usually needs to be handled specially. This method returns `Nothing` if the value is `Nothing` - so the caller can try to treat this value as fitting any type, or accordingly to specific semantics of each method.

name: resolve_operation_kind
description: Returns the operation kind based on types of the inputs, or an error if the inferred kinds are incompatible. If both inputs are Null, it is impossible to tell the kind, so Nothing is returned and the caller may decide what to do.

name: resolve_addition_kind
description: A helper which resolves if numeric addition or string concatenation should be used when the a `+` operator is used with the two provided types. It will return an error if the provided types are incompatible.

name: resolve_subtraction_kind
description: A helper which resolves if numeric subtraction or date-time difference should be used when the a `-` operator is used with the two provided types. It will return an error if the provided types are incompatible.

name: check_binary_numeric_op
description: Checks that both provided arguments have numeric type and runs the action if they do.

name: check_binary_boolean_op
description: Checks that both provided arguments have boolean type and runs the action if they do.

name: check_multi_argument_comparable_op
description: Checks that all provided argument are comparable with the provided column.

name: is_decimal_integer
description: Checks if `Value_Type.Decimal` represents integers.

name: Leaf
description: A leaf in the vector builder.

name: Append
description: A node that appends the two child nodes.

name: empty
description: Creates an empty vector builder.

name: from_vector
description: Creates a vector builder from a vector.

name: length
description: Number of elements inside of the to-be-built vector.

name: is_empty
description: Checks if this builder contains any elements.

name: not_empty
description: Checks if this builder is not empty.

name: build
description: Materializes the actual vector from this builder.

Concatenates another builder or vector to this. 

 It returns a new builder that will yield a vector that is a concatenation of `self` and the argument.

description: Creates a new column with the count of unique items in the selected column(s) within each group. If no rows, evaluates to 0.

name: Count_Not_Nothing
description: Creates a new column with the count of not `Nothing` (null) values of the specified column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to 0.

name: Count_Nothing
description: Creates a new column with the count of `Nothing` (null) values of the specified column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to 0.

name: Count_Not_Empty
description: Creates a new column with the count of not `Nothing` (null) and non-empty ("") values of the column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to 0.

name: Count_Empty
description: Creates a new column with the count of `Nothing` (null) or empty ("") text values of the column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to 0.

name: Sum
description: Creates a new column with the sum of values (ignoring missing values) of the column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to `Nothing`.

name: Average
description: Creates a new column with the mean of values (ignoring missing values) of the column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to `Nothing`.

name: Median

name: Percentile

name: Mode

name: Standard_Deviation
description: Creates a new column with the standard deviation of values (ignoring missing values) of the column within each group. If no rows, evaluates to `Nothing`.

name: Concatenate
description: Creates a new column with the values concatenated together. `Nothing` values will become an empty string. If no rows, evaluates to `Nothing`.

name: First

name: Last

name: Maximum

name: Minimum

name: Shortest

name: Longest

name: All_Cells
